description:
Strategic Gears is the biggest local management consultancy firm in Saudi Arabia. It has offices in Egypt, Qatar, and the UK. The company provides multidisciplinary services for both the private and public sectors. It offers consulting solutions in the areas of Strategy, Marketing, Organizational Excellence, and Digital and Technology to a range of clients in both the public and private sectors.

The company is heavily involved in the transformation era of Saudi Arabia, driven by the Vision 2030 initiatives. Strategic Gears prides itself on its ability to be a knowledge hub for the Saudi market, publishing reports every month on the current state of the Kingdomâ€™s economy as well as hot topics in both the public and private sectors, including an annual coverage of the Saudi budget, and other reports on the Kingdomâ€™s macroeconomic performance, labour market, digital transformation and AI, among others. The company, which was founded in late 2015, has quickly evolved from a small team to more than 240 employees in all its branches.

With the right interventions, Saudi Arabia can unlock $32 billion in untapped non-oil exports, with plastics and chemicals representing the most promising lever. In our recent research, we identified 3 high-potential product segments for the Kingdom:

1. Core-competitive products, where exports are competitive and have a high commercial value.
2. Scalable products, where exports are competitive but commercially underleveraged.
3. Near-competitive products, where exports have a high-return opportunity but are on the cusp of competitiveness.

Within the core-competitive product base, plastics, organic chemicals, and fertilizers generate over 70% of potential revenues. To close these gaps, a targeted strategy to scale the front-runners is key and can take the form of continued investment in quality, technology upgrades, and market access.

With the right interventions, Saudi Arabia can unlock an unrealized export opportunity of $10 billion in just two markets. Actual exports to China are $9.8 billion, with an untapped potential of $7.6 billion; and export levels to the U.S., which currently hover between $2 billion and $3 billion, have the potential to almost double.

These gaps signal markets where demand exists, Saudi products are competitive, and access is viable, but supply has not yet scaled to match.
To close the gaps, coordinated efforts from policy and business leaders are required. Two key actions carry high return: one, adapting products to meet the packaging, labeling, and regulatory and consumer expectations of target markets, and two, strengthening market intelligence capabilities to be prepared for any shifts in demand, policy, and competitor activity.

Nearly half of all aircraft imported by China in 2024 came from the U.S.â€”but beyond that, American goods barely register.

Data shows that Chinaâ€™s imports from the U.S. are narrowly focused, centered around a limited number of high-value categories. Aerospace stands out, while other sectorsâ€”such as oil seeds, medical devices, and pharmaceuticalsâ€”register modest volumes that exhibit pockets of dependence.

This pattern shows Chinaâ€™s selective reliance on the U.S. for highly specialized goods that are difficult to substitute. For most categories, however, the U.S. plays a marginal roleâ€”suggesting that future market entry will depend less on scale and more on differentiation.

For Saudi exporters looking to enter the Chinese market, this points to the importance of precision over breadth. Rather than broad diversification, the focus could be on niche categories where Chinaâ€™s dependency exceeds 20%. Competitive positioning will likely rest on factors such as regulatory quality, technical performance, and alignment with agricultural or health standards.

Successful entry may be supported by tailored commercial agreements, credible compliance infrastructure, and long-term investment in reputation and reliability.

Nearly $600 billion in disrupted trade flows is redrawing the global sourcing map. Much of this turmoil stems from the shifting dynamics between the worldâ€™s two largest economies. An asymmetry in trade relianceâ€”where the U.S. depends heavily on Chinese imports, while China sources most of its imports from other countriesâ€”has magnified the consequences of trade barriers. Between 2022 and 2024, the U.S. consistently sourced 14â€“17% of its imports from China, while China obtained over 93% of its imports from non-U.S. suppliers. 

This reshaping of global supply and demand patterns has opened new spaces for countries ready to step in. Saudi Arabia can expand its role as a competitive exporter in categories where U.S. dependency is high and diversification is overdueâ€”particularly plastics, fertilizers, and chemicals.
Â 
Policymakers and exporters have an opportunity to take strategic action on several fronts: target high-dependency sectors in the U.S. import basket where substitution is both necessary and viable; accelerate trade facilitation measures to ease access to the market; align domestic production strategies with emerging demand patterns; and invest in reliability, quality standards, and compliance infrastructure to position Saudi products as default alternatives in disrupted supply chains.Â  

The full findings are available in our latest report on post-tariff trade dynamics: https://lnkd.in/gSxXrQKZ

Strategy failure is a problem that occurs far more often than it should, with over half happening after significant time and monetary resources have been spent by an organization. How can leaders remedy this?

In this perspective piece, Laith Abdin, Partner at Strategic Gears, provides a walkthrough of a four-pillar framework that can better help organizations turn their strategies into practice.
